I wonder if I'm one of the few people here that instantly gets the difference between crushing resistance and impact resistance. When pressure is evenly applied to a material at a slow rate it is (typically) easier to withstand. When the same amount of pressure is quickly applied to a material it causes a shockwave to ripple through the material making microscopic (or smaller) changes/waves to/in the material causing it to fail easier. It's similar to the difference between a push and a punch.

Just FYI... I have 7 rules for doing a PhD - never ever ever ever ever ever ever do a PhD. Unless you really want to...

it sounds like a cheap shot, but it isn't. I like it because it's humorous but I really did have 7 rules... most were personal but a few stand out...

1) Don't rush in... I wish I hadn't done mine straight out of grad school - 5 years on, I would have done so much better with some experience behind me, and the mindset of someone who has returned to study. I think you got this covered...

2) pick a subject you are absolutely passionate about. Don't compromise on this. it's likely you will face times when you stop caring - picking something you love minimises this risk.

3) choose a supervisor carefully - during my 4th year I had 2 - both knew nothing about the others subject matter, so I had to translate - consequently I knew both areas rather well... It is a good approach to take... (I had 3 supervisors - none of whom knew my subject well)

4) most important of all - it's very easy to give up your social life to squeeze in time for the study. It's necessary, in fact. But. Don't give it all up. Interacting with other people - socially, professionally, is so vitally important. I can't emphasis this one enough... other people are the core of your success in a PhD... or.. anything really... I made this mistake big time... took me years to recover... (I honestly believe there is an entire research department worth of PhD's in the study of mental illness and higher degrees... if but for the fact they'd all go nuts...)

Very cool opportunities Destin is giving out. I have a few words of caution for the prospective undergraduate: make sure you are getting some form of recognition for your work. This could take the form of being included in the author lists for any published research, or (more likely for undergrad ) giving poster presentations at conferences. These are the building blocks that future employers or graduate schools are going to be looking for -- they want proof you can work and then present your findings! Ask these questions before you commit your time to someone else's research:
"What research journals do you publish in? How often?"
"Do you ever include undergraduates in the list of authors?"
"If I work for three years but you publish in five, will I still be an author?"
"Can I take the research results I did here and present them at a poster session?"
"What conferences have poster sessions I can attend? Are they yearly conferences?"
"Will you help me create a poster or am I on my own? Will the grant money that is paying me also pay for my expenses when presenting?"
